author: Hibiki_Kenzaki
body: My pick: Ansys. Solid history of growth, potential connectivity with metaverse application. And finally, solid industry demand from all sectors.

author: shantired
body:
I buy/maintain $100’s of K’s of Ansys licenses every year.

It’s a niche software (used in almost all branches of HW engineering such as ME/EE/RF). Recently they have touted ADAS as a focus area.

Don’t get me wrong, but very expensive niche software programs like Ansys exist because specialist engineers require that capability.

Their SW requires very expensive HW to run as well- we are talking about multi processor, multiple core Xeons, TBs of RAM etc. requires lots of maintenance as well.

A better play for them would be to move the SW to the cloud and host it on supercomputer instances. Even with super duper servers, some of my Ansys simulations take days to run, and we could reduce our design time considerably if we have access to supercomputers.

Just my $0.02 (as a user/procurer of their SW), they are growing but it’s not a spreadsheet like Excel or Gsuite that can make billions unless they rationalize their offering by offering supercomputing as a service, as that will open up their addressable market to smaller engineering companies.

author: CnC-
body:
Very good simulation software although I believe they lack a strong CAD solution. 

IMO integrated CAD/CAE platforms are the future of engineering. 3Dexperience from Dassault, for example, offers a much better connection between a strong CAD solution (CATIA), a great FE core (abaqus) and decent postprocessing (Fesafe). Together with the automation features of the 3dexperience platform, it is a much more powerful tool than Ansys workbench in structural analysis. Fluid simulations are a different story (PM me if you want to know more, don't know if anyone cares for more details).

Long story short: I wouldn't invest in ANSYS based on my experiences as an engineer. However, I haven't looked at any other numbers/fundamentals. Those may tell a different story.

author: Infinityaero
body: I remember browsing that looking for things to poach for my own positions and the only good one that jumped out was Ansys (ANSS) which makes modeling and simulation software heavily used in the Aerospace industry... that was a good buy I'm guessing it was one of the few winners in that pile though.

author: reddit_again__
body: As a user. Ansys is the best simulation package.

author: maxvesper
body:
I'm a control systems engineer in an aerospace company and I use ANSYS Scade. There's now a huge demand for control systems engineers/designers fueled by the fast growing EV sector. And I'm in Canada, it must be even crazier in the US.
ANSYS is basically a pick-and-shovel play.

author: gnocchicotti
body:
The fact that cloud deployments are not the default use case and they haven't been pushing that integration hard says all you need to know about their direction.

I haven't used Ansys exactly but all engineering software I'm familiar with lags the state of the art by 5-15 years. That's by design - they're niche software and they only exist to extract huge amounts of money from tiny user bases, and the added features over time seem more about breaking compatibility with old versions than moving the product forward and improving productivity.

Big software trends that engineering/scientific has been late to adopt even though they stand the most to gain:

-shift from single threaded to multithreaded optimization (workstations now can have up to 256 threads, not 4)

-massively parallel processing for tasks that support it, completing tasks in a fraction of the time as CPU computing

-API to allow integrating functionality into 3rd party apps or integrated systems, locally or remotely

-Support for virtual environments and virtual desktops (already old tech now) which lead to cloud deployments with scalable performance for huge, distributed teams, and more recently to the insane supercomputer-class instances available from some of the big cloud vendors that allow institutions to completely bypass the hardware acquisition and IT infrastructure process, and solve problems that might take days or weeks on a workstation in a matter of minutes.

The best thing that could happen I think would be if some of these legacy scientific companies could get acquired by actually competent software/infrastructure companies with vision like Nvidia or Microsoft, and they get dragged into the 21st century. As is, none of those dinosaurs are going to be the Nvidia of 2030 because they're still trying to be the Microsoft of 2002. (I'll give a little bit of a pass to Autodesk on this because they seem to have some sort of vision with their Fusion360 product.)

author: on606
body:
From seeking alpha.

The Trade Desk (NASDAQ:TTD) is scheduled to announce Q3 earnings results on Monday, November 8th, before market open.

The consensus EPS Estimate is $0.15 (-88.2% Y/Y) and the consensus Revenue Estimate is $283.93M (+31.4% Y/Y).

Over the last 2 years, TTD has beaten EPS estimates 100% of the time and has beaten revenue estimates 100% of the time.

Over the last 3 months, EPS estimates have seen 12 upward revisions and 0 downward. Revenue estimates have seen 13 upward revisions and 0 downward.￼

Trade Desk's peers HubSpot (NYSE:HUBS), ANSYS (NASDAQ:ANSS), Bill.com Holdings (NYSE:BILL) Paycom Software (NYSE:PAYC) have already reported their quarterly results.

HubSpot Q3 results topped analysts' forecasts and also gave a slightly better-than-expected Q4 outlook; Meanwhile ANSYS, Bill.com and Paycom also beat analysts' estimates.

Trade Desk's stock declined -3.24% on Aug. 9, the day it reported its Q2 results.

Q2 earnings topped expectations and the company had issued upside guidance for Q3.

Revenues doubled the total from Q2 last year, hitting $280M, and net income nearly doubled, to $47.7M on a GAAP basis, and to $88.2M non-GAAP (from $44.8M).

In October, the company inked a global partnership with Xiaomi to access Xiaomi’s global audience through its mobile ad offerings directly via The Trade Desk platform.

author: jeffreyianni
body: Numerous simultaneous interconnected systems is simply more similar to GPU architecture than CPU. This existed before Ansys took advantage of it, not the other way around. Just as the properties of geometry existed before humans described them with mathematics.

author: maxvesper
body: I work for Pratt & Whitney, we use ANSYS SCADE for engine control systems design. Great tool. SCADE has an edge over MATLAB/Simulink for safety critical applications.
